title: U.S. Durable Orders Rose for Third Straight Month in August
text:
By Paul Kiernan and Sarah Chaney

WASHINGTON--Orders for long-lasting goods rose in August for a third straight month thanks to a surge in orders for military aircraft. Other components, including a proxy for business investment, were softer, however. Here are the key takeaways from the report:

-Orders for durable goods--products designed to last at least three years, such as computers and machinery-increased 0.2% from the prior month to a seasonally adjusted $250.67 billion in August, the Commerce Department said Friday.

-Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had expected a 1% drop in the month.

-Orders for July were up an unrevised 2% from June.

-Compared with August 2018, demand for durable products was down 4.2%.

-A closely watched proxy for business investment, new orders for nondefense capital goods excluding aircraft, fell 0.2% in August from July to $69.3 billion. It was down 1.7% from August 2018.

-Friday's report showed orders for defense aircraft and parts surging 30% in August from July, helping to keep overall durable-goods orders positive even as orders for civilian aircraft fell.

-The Commerce Department's durable goods orders report can be found at http://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3.
